newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNI FOCUS--prices ease, outpacing Treasuries.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNI FOCUS--prices ease, outpacing Treasuries.

text.p: U.S. municipal bonds at midday Wednesday were pegged from unchanged to down an eighth to a quarter of a point in spots, as the market resisted some of the downward pressure exerted by Treasury bonds.
"I would say it's off, probably no more than a quarter of a point, probably an eighth to a quarter of a point on generic, dollar bonds," a trader said.
New York City, whose $739 million of general obligation bonds was the deal of the week, saw its debt priced with a top yield of six percent in 2016, according to Lehman Brothers.

Traders said that while retail interest might have been dampened during the presale period by concerns about whether the Federal Reserve would raise rates when its policy-makers met on Tuesday, they expected the offering to go fairly smoothly. The central bank left interest rates unchanged.
"I thought it (New York City) was priced right, I thought the adjustment on the insured (portion) was good, I put in for a lot of bonds," a trader said.
Still, he cautioned that because the offering, a refunding, is made up of serial not term bonds, it might be a bit more difficult to trade in the secondary market.
A shortfall of municipal bonds was one of the main reasons cited for the market's recent ability to outperform Treasuries.
The Standard and Poor's Corp Blue List, a yardstick of secondary supply, stood at almost $1.1 billion, a fairly lean level.

Traders said the municipal market's resilience was working against it in at least one respect: individual investors, who expected to prices to be marked down as much as Treasury bonds displayed little interest at the present levels.
"It's very hard to tell clients municipals are not cheaper when they see governments go down," a trader said.

Treasury bonds firmed from lows after falling sharply when the U.S. trade gap came in much narrower than expected, sliding 19.3 percent to $8.51 billion. This was well below forecasts for a $10.3 billion gap seen in a Reuters consensus poll of economists.

A Chase Securities Inc economist, noting exports were higher than anticipated, said he now expected the first quarter Gross Domestic Product to be revised up, with a less unfavorable outlook for trade in the second quarter.

June municipal bond futures traded on the Chicago Board of Trade slipped five ticks to 116-18/32, while the June U.S. Treasury bonds lost 11 ticks to 109-16/32. This left the MOB spread at a robust plus 226 ticks, roughly 10 ticks stronger than on Tuesday.
Alliance Airport Authority Inc Texas Special Facilities Revenues of 2021, which pay a 6-3/8 percent coupon, were bid at 101-3/8, up an eighth of a point.
And Dade County, Florida, Water and Sewer System Revenus of 2025, which have a 5-1/2 percent coupon, were bid at 5.70 percent, down two basis points.
